Alabama
Annotation Text: A 2011 tornado path from Tuscaloosa to Birmingham, Alabama, USA is shown in red. Tornado frequency in the southeast USA is expected to increase due to global warming.

Annotation Title: Yakutsk
Annotation Text: Boreal forest fire dynamics are illustrated for Yakutsk, eastern Siberia, Russia. Fire frequency, extent and severity are likely to increase with global warming.

Annotation Title: Mozambique
Annotation Text: Most of African land change is due to smallholder agriculture, where families clear woodlands and forest to grow crops. The sustainability of such systems given burgeoning populations is threatened as they require fallow periods for land to recover before subsequent clearing. The threats to biodiversity are great as humans encroach on the remaining natural woodland and forest ecosystems.

Annotation Title: Indonesia
Annotation Text: Industrial scale clearing of tropical forests to produce palm oil and wood products is clear in Riau, Sumatra, Indonesia. Palm oil is found in many household products and foods and is produced only in the humid tropics. Humid tropical forests are the most biodiverse on the planet and their replacement by monoculture palm estates and tree plantations results in ecosystem collapse.

Annotation Title: Paraguay
Annotation Text: Paraguay is the site of one of the highest deforestation rates globally, from its Interior Atlantic Forests in the east to Chaco woodlands in the west. Land is cleared for row crops or pastures, with little area set aside for nature or indigenous reserves.

Annotation Title: Cote D'Ivoire
Annotation Text: Forest loss within protected areas in Cote D'Ivoire is evident and related to the two civil wars of 2002 and 2007 and a resulting breakdown in governance. The dynamic points out the fragility of protected area networks which on paper can cover a substantial area of a given country, but are subject to exploitation in times of conflict.

Annotation Title: Kalimantan
Annotation Text: Like Sumatra, Kalimantan, Indonesia is the site of large-scale agroindustrial clearing. Kalimantan's peatlands, habitat for orangutans and extensive carbon stores in peatland soils, are increasingly appropriated for palm oil production. The interior highlands are logged, but not cleared as extensively as accessible lowland and wetland forests.

Annotation Title: Sarawak
Annotation Text: The border of Malaysia and Indonesia on the island of Borneo reveals a variation in forest exploitation between the two countries. Interior Borneo is the site of intensive high-grading of high value tropical forests on the Malaysian side of the border. The Heart of Borneo conservation initiative will likely rely on the Indonesian side of the border for conserving the unique ecosystem services of montane Borneo forests.

Annotation Title: Russia/Finland
Annotation Text: Under Soviet rule, a buffer of forest was maintained along the Russian-Finland border. Recent access to this forest under Russian governance has led to increased forest clearing. The Finland side of the border reflects a long-held smallholder forestry land use, and a lack of intact natural forests.

Pittsburgh
Annotation Text: Pittsburgh, USA, demonstrates long-term exurban growth, with significant greenspace loss rather than through densification.

Annotation Title: Pittsburgh
Annotation Text: Pittsburgh's evolution demonstrates residential and industrial sites intermingled, bringing questions of airshed and watershed toxicity to the forefront as major emissions, residences and schools all collocate.

Annotation Title: Lagos
Annotation Text: Lagos, Nigeria has witnessed massive growth, from 17 million in 2006 to over 20 million today.

Annotation Title: Lagos
Annotation Text: Living resources of water and forest in Lagos, Nigeria are threatened by massive growth due to economic opportunity. This combination demands thoughtful and long-term planning.

Annotation Title: Seoul
Annotation Text: Seoul, Korea demonstrated long-term urban protected area planning with regions such as Bukhansan National Park, preserving greenspace during urban densification.

Annotation Title: Seoul
Annotation Text: Seoul, Korea demonstrated long-term urban protected area planning with regions such as Bukhansan National Park, preserving greenspace during urban densification.

Annotation Title: Shenzhen
Annotation Text: The Pearl River Delta in China has witnessed massive population explosions, with Shenzhen growing from a mere 40,000 inhabitants to 40 million in three decades. Massive land use transformations can be seen in concert with this rapid growth.

Annotation Title: Brasilia
Annotation Text: Brasilia, Brazil includes the largest national urban park in the world, protecting tropical savanna and forest in order to balance development with greening and preservation.

Annotation Title: Northwest of Brasilia
Annotation Text: Brasilia, Brazil includes the largest national urban park in the world, protecting tropical savanna and forest in order to balance development with greening and preservation.

Annotation Title: Milano
Annotation Text: The forestation of agricultural areas around Milan, Italy serves as an example of conservation management, now prevalent in numerous locales throughout Europe.

Annotation Title: Duisburg
Annotation Text: Germany has increased its forest cover by more than 3%, thanks to explicit forestation policies surrounding urban areas.

Annotation Title: Pretoria, South Afria
Annotation Text: Urbanization in the Jo'burg - Pretoria corridor has greatly increased urban land use throughout Gauteng Province, placing industrial and residential activities close together as in other industrial, growing locales around the world.

Annotation Title: Nairobi
Addis Ababa
Lake Urmia
Annotation Text: The gradual disappearance of Lake Urmia in Iran is a token of resource shifts today, culmination from short-term human decisions combined with long-term global trends. These markers of change are near-time exemplars of long-term changes in watershed, arable land and climate dynamics that shift opportunities globally.

Annotation Title: Coral Reefs
Annotation Text: Today we can map every coral reef, and we can visualize bleaching events annually over decades, helping to understand visually the global impact of changes in ocean chemistry now underway.
